item.content:encoded:
This assignment compares the Missa Brevis by two composers, Palestrina and Zoltán Kodály. Additionally, it examines Max Richter’s reinterpretation of Vivaldi’s Four Seasons in his work, Vivaldi Recomposed.

Part 1

To compare the Missa Brevis by Palestrina and Zoltán Kodály, I listened to The Tallis Scholars’ recording of Palestrina’s Mass, directed by Peter Phillips, and to the Warsaw Philharmonic Choir’s performance of Kodály’s Mass directed by Bartosz Michałowski.

Palestrina’s Missa Brevis exemplifies the Renaissance style. Composed for four voices sometime in the mid-16th century, it adheres to the principles of counterpoint, with melodic lines weaving together seamlessly. The focus is on vocal clarity and a sense of serenity. Palestrina’s textures are predominantly smooth, with a balance between polyphony and homophony, usually manifesting at the final cadence. The overall effect is one of meditative beauty, drawing the listener into a realm of introspection. Palestrina’s works were typically performed with no accompaniment in large, resonant spaces, allowing the polyphonic textures to blend and create a sense of reverence and spaciousness.

Kodály’s Missa Brevis for solo voices, chorus, and organ, was composed during World War II (1942-44), reflecting a contrasting world. It is imbued with significance, having premiered in the cloakroom of Budapest’s Opera House. Subtitled “in tempore belli” (“in times of war”), it was written, at least in part, during the Budapest siege. This sense of despair is infused in the composition through the use of dissonances and the interaction between the voices. Kodály’s Missa Brevis is more outward-looking, with a sense of energy and drama that contrasts with Palestrina’s introspective nature. It also distances itself from Palestrina’s Mass by incorporating more rhythmic vitality and a greater emphasis on the expressive potential of the human voice.

In terms of tonality, it is centred on D and its structure forms an arch, a nineteenth-century structural principle (Pickar, 1985), with extensive use of thematic transformation: the Adagio ‘Qui tollis’ from the Gloria returns at the start of the Agnus Dei. A variation of the entire Kyrie is employed for the ‘Dona nobis pacem’. The cadences feel more unexpected than those found in Palestrina’s compositions.

Despite their stylistic differences, both composers share a common core. They adhere to the traditional structure of the Mass Ordinary, comprising sections like Kyrie, Gloria, Credo, Sanctus, Benedictus, and Agnus Dei, although Kodály adds an introductory section (Introitus) and a final section (Ite, Missa Est). They also employ the traditional Latin text of the Mass. Kodály’s Missa Brevis features plainchant-style melodies similar to Palestrina but mixed with modal keys reminiscent of the Hungarian folk tradition.

Being passionate about WWII history, Kodály’s Mass naturally feels more interesting to me. Its historical importance attracted me right away, but so did the sound of it. It feels more explorative than Palestrina’s, even while following an established structure. The beginning of Gloria is a great example of unexpected fanfare-like figures. The interaction between the voices, almost like a dialogue, appeals to me more. The drama, the use of dissonance, and the unexpected cadences also draw me toward Kodály’s Mass.

Ultimately, I feel that Kodaly’s Mass is rooted in tonality and isn’t as challenging to the ear as other contemporary musical pieces, such as Bartók’s. This made me appreciate the music more. Perhaps it was Kodaly’s background as a music educator that led him to make a more accessible Mass, or maybe he aimed to create a Mass that would reach a broader audience and bring peace and hope in a post-war setting.”

Word: 548

References

Pickar, C. (1985) ‘An analytical process applied to Kodály’s ‘Missa Brevis’ on JSTOR,’ The Choral Journal, 26(3), pp. 7–12. https://www.jstor.org/stable/23546905.

Stevens, H. (1968) ‘THE CHORAL MUSIC OF ZOLTÁN KODÁLY,’ The Musical Quarterly, LIV(2), pp. 147–168. https://doi.org/10.1093/mq/liv.2.147.

Part 2

Vivaldi Recomposed is a piece composed by Max Richter in 2011, where he proposed to pick up the essence of Vivaldi’s Four Seasons and imbue it with a contemporary sound (Vivaldi’s The Four Seasons recomposed by Max Richter [Streaming], 2014). But rather than merely rearranging Vivaldi’s composition to mirror the modern aesthetic, Richter deconstructs the original piece. He isolates its fundamental elements—themes, harmonies, and rhythms—and reassembles them, allowing the work to resonate deeply with today’s audiences. This analysis examines the Winter Concerto to understand how Richter creates a fresh sound while using earlier material.

Before looking into the piece, it’s crucial to understand that Richter, like any composer, did not create in isolation. His work is a product of the 21st-century context. This implies that both he and his audience are familiar with Vivaldi’s Four Seasons since it is one of the most popular classical pieces in the world. Moreover, composers who emerged after Vivaldi introduced new techniques and sounds, influencing Richter’s compositions.

This influence is evident in the first segment of Winter 1. The first 22 bars mirror exactly Vivaldi’s Winter First Movement. However, Richter introduces a new technique. He instructs all the strings to use Ponticello, see Fig. 1, generating a shivering and harsh sound. While Ponticello was used occasionally in the Baroque period, it was only during the Romantic Period that Ponticello evolved into a significant expressive tool, rather than merely a unique sound effect (Greenfield, 2017). The effect is particularly pronounced in the solo violin, which produces a sound that is significantly colder and more glass-like than Vivaldi’s.

Richter’s usage of dynamics also diverges from Vivaldi’s. Where Vivaldi maintains a constant mezzo-forte until the crescendo for a forte before the main them, Richter engages in a dynamic fluctuation, repeatedly crescendo from pianissimo to mezzo-forte or forte, see Fig. 2, before each of solo violin line. This manipulation of dynamics enhances the overall texture and emotional depth of the piece, underpinning Richter’s vision.

Perhaps the most thrilling aspect of Richter’s Winter 1 is his approach to reconfiguring Vivaldi’s most recognisable passage of the movement. Richter decided to extract a beat from the main theme, transitioning from a 4/4 to a 7/16 time signature, see Fig. 3. This imparts an unexpected sound to a familiar part of the music. It renders the music rapid, restless, and somewhat sloppy, effectively conveying the sensation of someone running on ice and occasionally slipping.

The rest of the first movement repeats this progression and rhythm until the end. The constant repetition of Vivaldi’s selected material is a hallmark of Richter’s recomposition, which one can understand comes from his minimalistic roots. Or perhaps it is so the work is more appealing to modern ears. In this case, in particular, he repeats the chord progression that moves in 4ths, see Fig 4. (which Vivaldi already used). This is a progression that has been extensively used in modern pop music, and the repetition likely satisfies the sensibilities of contemporary audiences.

The second movement, “Winter 2,” is impressive in its simplicity and coldness. Here, Richter utilizes two of Vivaldi’s original materials – the melody, which is almost the same as the original except for some additional tremolos and brief skipping of notes, and the drone of the viola, which he multiplies across all the strings. This seems a Richter stylistic trace, reminiscent of his piece “A Sudden Manhattan of the Mind,” where a drone harmony (played by synths in this case) creates a soundscape for the violin to display its melody.

The harmonic inaction evokes a sensation of stillness, coldness, and sadness, which contrasts with Vivaldi’s programmatic feeling of pleasure in getting warm inside through a crackling fire. This is perhaps the most impressive feature of Richter’s recomposition – using almost identical material (in this case, the melody and drone) to convey a completely different, and in fact, opposing emotional experience.

Allowing for an almost static harmony gives solo performers significant creative expression, particularly in live performances, where the tempo can be stretched or reduced without impacting the accompaniment. This aspect hints at Richter’s dedication to continue Vivaldi’s legacy of showcasing musical virtuosity.

In Winter 3 there’s Richter’s signature style of stability, defined by Ross (2023), when he writes “Richter’s pieces usually wind up not far from where they began”. This movement evokes a sense of a vast, seemingly unchanging landscape, subtly layered with the introduction of individual elements, one at a time, without any dramatic harmonic or rhythmic shifts. This aligns perfectly with Szabo’s definition of minimalism: “uniform, predictable, and understated music; lacking in abrupt changes of instrumentation or volume, devoid of harmonic or rhythmic surprises” (Ross, 2023). Here, Richter unquestionably embraces a minimalist approach to Vivaldi’s material.

He steers away from Vivaldi’s programmatic movement, creating an enigmatic soundscape that feels perpetually unsettled. While a subtle programmatic hint lingers through the repeated descending scales in the violas, in red in Fig. 5, suggesting a sensation of constant falling, the solo violin’s unending ostinatos (green) and contrabass drone (blue) establish an ethereal atmosphere that defies a strictly programmatic interpretation.

Another noteworthy distinction is Richter’s omission of the unexpected pauses and changes of mood employed by Vivaldi in his third movement. Here, the rhythm persists uniformly throughout, further emphasising the minimalist avoidance of rhythmic surprises.

The ending of the movement fades out rather than resolving with a definitive cadence, a technique prevalent in many popular songs, particularly those from the latter half of the 20th century (Weir, 2014). This is particularly intriguing for a piece’s final resolution. One traditionally anticipates a conclusive ending, mirroring Vivaldi’s approach. Here, however, Richter offers a gentle, introspective, and open-ended conclusion.

Upon revisiting Vivaldi Recomposed, it becomes evident that Richter’s process involved more than simply layering new material upon Vivaldi’s foundation. Notably, Richter introduces no entirely new melodies. Instead, he employs a technique of repetition, similar to looping and sampling – a decidedly modern soundscape. Through this approach, Richter creates a piece that bridges the centuries, fostering a dialogue between an old work and the present day. This strategy allows Richter to both preserve and redefine Vivaldi’s composition, ensuring its continued relevance and connection with contemporary audiences.

Word: 1024

References

Ross, A. (2023) ‘The doleful minimalism of Max Richter,’ The New Yorker, 10 April. https://www.newyorker.com/magazine/2023/04/17/max-richter-music-review.

How I wrote… Vivaldi’s Four Seasons Recomposed – Max Richter (2014). https://www.classicfm.com/composers/richter/news/vivaldi-recomposed-interview/.

Vivaldi’s The Four Seasons recomposed by Max Richter [Streaming] (2014). Isis Productions for Deutsche Grammophon. https://edu-medici-tv.rpa.sccl.org/en/documentaries/vivaldi-the-four-seasons-recomposed-by-max-richter-the-berlin-concert-george-scott.

Weir, W. (2014) ‘The sad, gradual decline of the Fade-Out in popular music,’ Slate Magazine, 15 September. https://slate.com/culture/2014/09/the-fade-out-in-pop-music-why-dont-modern-pop-songs-end-by-slowly-reducing-in-volume.html.

Greenfield, L. (2017) Extended string techniques and special effects in Arnold Schoenberg’s string Quartet No. 1 and its significance in chamber music literature. Dissertation Prepared for the Degree of DOCTOR OF MUSICAL ARTS. University of North Texas. https://digital.library.unt.edu/ark:/67531/metadc1011750/m2/1/high_res_d/GREENFIELD-DISSERTATION-2017.pdf.

Reflective Account

The Renaissance and Baroque eras are not my favorite musical periods. While I recognise their importance to music history, the complexity of the contrapuntal music and the strict adherence to forms are two aspects that put me off. However, I found it extremely useful to gain knowledge of forms, instruments, techniques and composers of these eras.

One particular sound that doesn’t appeal to me in these periods is sacred music, especially because of its stillness, slow rhythms, and the echoing polyphony of the voices. I’ve tried to listen to several pieces, and this unit was helpful in that regard as well, but I still struggle to find pleasure in listening to them. That was until I listened to Kodály’s Missa Brevis. That was a real pleasure to listen to. Although it had the same slowness of a Renaissance style, it had a lot of dissonance that I felt adds a lot more drama and spice.

Reflecting and researching dissonance was interesting to the point that I’ve been much more drawn to dissonant sounds since I started my degree than ever before. I now appreciate dissonance as a spice in food. Too much can distract from the main flavours (meaning harmony and melody), but too little can make it bland and predictable. In the case of Kodály’s Missa Brevis, I felt that the dissonances were just right in making serene music sound more dramatic.

I feel that this unit’s assignment was when I explored more of one of the things I love most about the arts, and music in particular. I love to explore how modern artists are influenced by past artists, especially in popular music. I find a special pleasure in identifying little influences in modern compositions that can relate directly to previous artists and understanding how contemporary artists add to that. But to do this, it’s better to have a deep understanding of music history as a whole, and that’s how I found this unit to be so useful.

Reflecting and understanding musical patronage was another topic I found very interesting in this unit. I find it especially important right now, in a moment when there’s a big discussion about payment models for artists, since streaming services pay so little and music publishers seem to favor those artists who are profitable in terms of live music. This leaves emerging artists out of the way to have financial support to pursue their music.

Although I like the historical and theoretical part of music, I miss composition a lot. I believe that this unit, and this course in general, would benefit from having a strong mix of theory and practical composition throughout the units.

I end this unit still mixing up a little between the eras. It’s much easier and intuitive for me to discern between Classical and Romantic than it is to discern Classical from Baroque and Renaissance. I believe I should work more on this in future units during my degree.

Overall, this unit helped a lot to contextualise music historically and idiomatically, although I believe I need further studying in order to gain a deep understanding of each musical era.

Word: 522

item.content:encoded:
By my tutor’s suggestion, I heard the work Wendy Carlos did with the Clockwork Orange soundtrack and was amazed by the mixture of classical and electronic music, especially with Beethoven’s 9th symphony.

From my research, Carlos was one of the pioneers of synthesizers, working with Robert Moog to develop the famous Moog synthesizer. She launched the hugely controversial Switched-on Bach album with music by Bach performed on a Moog synthesizer. Later, she continued combining synthesized and classical music, and she combined Beethoven’s 9th Symphony with a new hardware that converted the human voice into electronic signals and would later be famously known as a vocoder.

This is the work that ended up in Clockwork Orange’s soundtrack and has an important role in it. Beethoven’s music works as a leitmotif for the main character, Alex, and violence. In the beginning, the music is acoustic, but after Alex’s shock therapy, the music is synthesized. The effect on the listener is quite radical and direct. What was once familiar, rooted in the past, and established, turns into a weird, futuristic, and almost childish sound. The vocoder works perfectly into making the famous choir turn into robots, which can be seen as a direct relation to what happens on screen: the deviant character is forced into normalcy.

Musically speaking, I really enjoyed listening to it. The sound sounds fresh even though it was composed in 1972, but that’s no surprise because synthesizers and vocoders are more and more common in contemporary music.

I heard this piece when trying to find pieces for the assignment. Although I would love to explore it in a deeper level, I didn’t find it fit the assignment context. Nevertheless, I listened to it several times, and found that it’s filled with romantic composers influences.

Muse, and especially its main composer, Matt Bellamy, are a contemporary rock band that is self-admittedly influenced by classical music. One can find direct usage of music from previous eras such as Palestrina’s Sanctus and Benedictus rearrangement in the music Drones; Saint-Saëns’s Mon cœur s’ouvre à ta voix in I Belong to You; and Tchaikovsky’s ‘Piano Concerto No.1: Allegro Non Troppo E Molto Maestoso in Hoodoo. But there are far more examples of direct influence such as Bach’s toccatas in Plug In Baby, The Handler and In Your World;

Exogenesis: Symphony is divided into three movements entitled “Overture”, “Cross-Pollination” and “Redemption, and has a programmatic story of humanity coming to an end and everyone pinning their hopes on a group of astronauts who go out to explore space and spread humanity to another planet. Matt Bellamy, the composer, said that this composition was “influenced by Rachmaninov, Strauss, Chopin and Pink Floyd.”

Right from the beginning of the piece, I can find similarities with Wagner’s The Rhinegold prelude. The floating arpeggios building up on top of a drone bass, creating a long and slow build up and setting the mood, made it look like at least the composer used the same style as Wagner’s. This establishes the beginning of the programme of humanity coming to an end.

When Bellamy’s voice enters, it is with a long falsetto that is not common in rock music. The several repeated questions that the lyrics present, go very well with the repetition of the arpeggios.

The second movement starts with only a piano playing a chromatic introduction that resembles Chopin’s Etude n°10 opus 25. The next part resembles Liszt’s Transcendental Etude No.5, Feux Follets. But another quick change in mood brings an accompaniment that sounds again like Chopin, in this case, his Nocturne op.9 n°2 in E flat Major.

The beginning of the third movement has a straightforward feeling of Beethoven’s Piano Sonata No. 14, mostly because of its triplets arpeggios, but for me it brought to mind the melody of Liszt’s Liebestraum No. 3 in the insisting high note.

Overall, I really liked this song, although it’s not my favourite from Muse, I like how they were able to mix classical influences in a somehow Rock Opera while at the same time sounding like Muse.”

item.description: Antonio Vivaldi, born in Venice in 1678, was a virtuoso violinist and composer, known for his innovative and…
item.content:encoded:
Antonio Vivaldi, born in Venice in 1678, was a virtuoso violinist and composer, known for his innovative and descriptive music. His father, a part-time professional violinist and flamboyant hairdresser, taught him the violin and instilled in him a love for the instrument. Vivaldi’s flaming ginger locks earned him the nickname “Red Priest” when he entered the clergy, but his asthma made it difficult for him to recite Mass, leading him to abandon his religious duties and become a violin teacher.

It was in 1712 that he wrote Violin Concerto in A minor, Op. 3 No. 6, the sixth concerto in his 12 concerto collection – L’Estro Armonico. Overall it sounded too virtuosic for the solo violin, especially the first and third movements.

The three movements offer a delightful journey through contrasting tempos and moods. The first movement is vibrant and energetic, with intricate melodies that challenge the violinist’s technical skills. In contrast, the Largo movement introduces a serene and contemplative atmosphere, allowing for expressive phrasing and emotional depth. The final movement brings a lively and spirited conclusion, showcasing a rhythmic drive and dynamic contrasts.

Vivaldi’s career took a significant turn when he became the music director of a Venetian orphanage in 1716, where he was tasked with writing two concertos a month for the all-girls orchestra. In 1718, he took a second job as Chapel Master for the governor of Mantua, where he found inspiration in the beautiful North Italian countryside. This led to the creation of his most famous work, The Four Seasons, which he dedicated to the orphan girls back home.

The Four Seasons is not a single piece, but a set of four separate violin concertos, each with three movements, that are part of a larger collection of 12 violin concertos titled “The Contest between Harmony and Invention.” Each concerto is written for solo violin, accompanied by violins, viola, and basso continuo, and corresponds to a specific season: Spring, Summer, Autumn, and Winter.

Vivaldi’s Four Seasons is considered one of the earliest examples of program music, as it is accompanied by a series of sonnets that describe the scenes and emotions of each season. Vivaldi printed the text of the sonnets in the music and even inserted descriptive words next to particular notes, guiding performers on how to interpret the piece.

Throughout he creates diverse settings with his music, translating the vivid sights and sensations of each season into an amazing sonic narrative. Despite the short instrumentation, his composition creates powerful and diverse settings for listeners to discover. The first concerto, Spring, opens with an infectiously happy theme, followed by a chorus of singing birds, a gentle breeze, and a thunderstorm. The second concerto, Summer, begins with the oppressive heat of the sun, a singing turtle dove, a goldfinch, and a violent storm. The third concerto, Autumn, celebrates the bountiful harvest with a village dance, a drunken display of virtuosity, and a hunting scene. The final concerto, Winter, depicts the harsh cold, an icy wind, the chattering of teeth, and a cosy fire.

Around the 1730s, Vivaldi’s later years were lived with financial struggles and a waning interest in his musical endeavours, as the shifting musical landscape of the Enlightenment era posed challenges to his traditional Baroque style. The decline in demand for his operatic works and the ban on opera performances following the death of Emperor Charles VI contributed to Vivaldi’s financial hardships and dwindling popularity in Vienna. Despite his erstwhile celebrity and wealth, Vivaldi’s final years were marred by poverty, culminating in his passing in 1741.

Despite his celebrity and riches in his lifetime, he died in poverty, and his extraordinary music slowly disappeared. The rediscovery of his music began in Italy when Alberto Gentilly, a lecturer in musical history at the University of Turin, made an unexpected and important musical discovery in 1927. He was sent to value a collection of music that was for sale at the Collegio San Marco in the small town of San Martino Natale. Gentilly found 14 volumes of music by Vivaldi, which contained 140 instrumental works, 29 cantatas, 12 operas, and an oratorio. It was an amazing find, but there was more excitement to come. Gentilly realized that half of the collection was missing, and he had a brainwave that it might be part of a split inheritance. He tracked down the rest of the collection and persuaded the reluctant aristocratic owner to sell it. Vivaldi, who had been regarded by experts as a minor figure of the Baroque era, was about to become a major star.

item.content:encoded:
Tomás Luis de Victoria was born around 1548 in Avila, Spain, and passed away in 1611 in Madrid. He is considered one of the greatest composers of the 16th century, alongside Palestrina and Orlando di Lasso. His career spanned both Spain and Italy, and he was known for his almost exclusively sacred and polyphonic vocal music, set to Latin texts.

Victoria was sent by King Philip II of Spain in 1565 to prepare for holy orders at the German College in Rome. He may have studied with Palestrina around this time, and certainly, he was influenced by the Italian style. He held various positions, including chapelmaster and instructor of plainsong. In 1575, Victoria was appointed Maestro di Capella at S. Apollinare.

Notably, Victoria devoted himself entirely to composing sacred music, unlike many of his peers who also composed secular works. His works include 21 masses and 44 motets. He also wrote psalm settings, hymns, several Magnificats, four offices for the dead, and music for Holy Week services. His last work was the Requiem Officium Defunctorum (1605) in memory of the empress Maria.

Victoria’s music is known for its depth of purpose, which I found very present in O Magnum Mysterium. He fused the contrapuntal technique of Palestrina with an intense dramatic feeling that is uniquely personal and deeply Spanish.

As for comments by his contemporaries, specific records are scarce. However, his influence on later Spanish composers was incalculable. His pupils included Manuel de Falla, Isaac Albéniz, and Enrique Granados. His editions of early Spanish music laid the foundations of Spanish musicology.

item.content:encoded:
Humanism is a philosophical stance that emphasizes the value and agency of human beings. Specifically, humanism affirms that human beings have the right and responsibility to give meaning and shape to their own lives, rather than have meaning imposed externally by a higher power. Humanism focuses on human values, capacities, and worth. It places importance on human dignity and rationality.

Humanism originated during the Renaissance in 14th-century Italy as a cultural movement promoting classical learning and values.

Some key principles of humanism include:

  • Emphasis on critical thinking and evidence over dogma
  • The belief that truth is discovered by human endeavour rather than revealed by a higher power
  • Commitment to the use of reason and science as ways of understanding the natural world and our place within it

The humanist focus on human dignity, potential, and values translated into music that highlighted the skills and creativity of individual composers and performers. Complex polyphonic styles and instrumental music developed to showcase composer and performer virtuosity.

Humanist themes praised human emotions, experiences, intellect, and achievements became common musical subject matter. Vocal music with texts exploring love, loss, joy, carpe diem etc reflected humanist ideals.

Humanism’s emphasis on earthly life led to the growing popularity of secular music styles like madrigals and dance music. The use of vernacular languages instead of Latin also became more common, reflecting humanist values.

item.title: Research Point: Dissonance in Music
item.dc:creator: Pedro
item.category: Part 5 Ars Nova, Renaissance and Baroque Music
item.description: In my research on the history of dissonance, I discovered an insightful video by Alan Belkin that shed…
item.content:encoded:
In my research on the history of dissonance, I discovered an insightful video by Alan Belkin that shed light on the evolution and usage of dissonance in music. Belkin makes a compelling point about the shift from vocal music to instrumental music and how this transition impacted the use of dissonance. Dissonance is more challenging to employ in vocal music, as singers must accurately hit the notes, especially when dealing with large intervals. In contrast, instruments can easily play virtually any interval.

Throughout music history, composers have used dissonance in various ways to achieve different effects. In the Baroque Era, composers like Bach utilised dissonance to build tension, which would then resolve to consonance. Bach employed suspension, creating dissonance that the ear accepts because it anticipates the resolution. This added drama and interest to the music.

During the Classical Era, composers like Mozart used dissonance sparingly to heighten emotion at strategic moments. Quick resolutions maintained overall harmonic stability. Mozart would occasionally insert dissonant notes into otherwise consonant themes, creating a playful dissonance.

In the Romantic Era, composers exploited dissonance more freely to convey intense emotions. Pieces often lingered in dissonance before resolving, using clashing intervals and chords to evoke strong feelings.

The 20th century saw composers like Arnold Schoenberg introduce the concept of the “emancipation of dissonance,” aiming to treat dissonant intervals and chords as equals with consonant ones. Additionally, microtonal music was created on top of dissonant sounds, generating micro-dissonances that could be subtle or very harsh.

In styles like jazz, dissonant seventh chords became fundamental building blocks of the harmonic language. For example, Gershwin’s harmonic language is infused with tangy flavors and impish energy through the use of juicy seventh chords.

Belkin argues that the true emancipation of dissonance lies not in using it constantly, but rather employing it strategically to create expressive effects. The perceived tension of dissonance depends on several factors, including the intervals between notes and the register (pitch) of the notes. The closer the notes are and the smaller the intervals between them, the more dissonance there is. However, there is a limit to how intense dissonance can become. A skilled composer will use dissonance purposefully to create expressive effects, rather than incorporating it merely for its own sake.

References

Alan Belkin (2019) Analysis for Composers #14 – on dissonance. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=TLLuZEGPns8.

Tommasini, A. (2014) ‘Musical dissonance, from Schumann to Sondheim,’ The New York Times, 30 May. https://www.nytimes.com/2014/06/01/arts/music/musical-dissonance-from-schumann-to-sondheim.html.

During the early Middle Ages (800-1450), the Catholic Church held significant power over many cultural aspects, including music. As the clergy and a select few were the only individuals capable of reading and writing, the Church was responsible for creating most music notation. These notations were meticulously crafted in highly decorative manuscripts known as illuminated manuscripts, which were carefully copied by scribes, often monks, onto parchment or vellum.

The process of handwriting and copying music was incredibly time-consuming and resource-intensive, with each manuscript requiring substantial effort to complete. This laborious process limited the number of copies of each piece of music, making the widespread distribution of music challenging. Additionally, the human factor introduced the possibility of errors, with each copy potentially containing inaccuracies rather than being a faithful reproduction of the original.

By the late 15th century, a new technique emerged for printing music, known as woodblock printing. In 1450, Johann Gutenberg’s invention of the printing press revolutionized the music world. With the advent of printing, the time and resources required to reproduce a sheet of music decreased significantly, leading to a rapid increase in the dissemination of musical scores across Europe. The fidelity of printing not only reduced the errors caused by human copying but also helped standardize musical notation.

One of the most significant impacts of the printing press was the reduction in the cost of reproducing music sheets. As scores became more accessible to musicians and the public, ideas and artistic movements spread more quickly, encouraging the development of new musical styles.

Although Gutenberg’s invention was a major breakthrough, other technological advancements also played a crucial role in disseminating music. Audio recording allowed for musical preservation and freed music from being locally confined. With recording technology, music performed in one part of the world could be experienced in another, providing a similar listening experience. Simultaneously, the widespread adoption of radio technology enabled music to be broadcast into homes, stimulating interest in various genres.

Ultimately, the internet has been a significant contributor to the widespread dissemination of music. In the present day, music is more accessible than ever, as digitized tracks can be instantly accessed globally, providing creators with platforms to share their work with a broad audience.

In conclusion, since Gutenberg’s invention, the dissemination of music has been closely tied to technological advancements. These developments have reduced the time and resources required to create and distribute music, making it more accessible to people around the world than ever before.

item.content:encoded:
Musical patronage has been a long-standing tradition in the world of arts, with its roots tracing back to ancient civilizations. It is a system where individuals or organizations provide financial support to musicians, enabling them to create and perform their work. This relationship between patrons and artists is complex and multifaceted, offering numerous advantages and some potential drawbacks.

One of the most apparent benefits of musical patronage is the financial support it provides to artists. Patrons offer direct financial backing, which allows musicians to focus on their creative work without the burden of financial worries. This financial stability can lead to a higher quality of work, as artists can devote their time and energy to honoring their craft rather than worrying about survival.

Musical patronage also extends its benefits to the wider community. Patrons who are familiar with the local music scene can support projects that benefit the community at large. This could involve funding music education programs, sponsoring community concerts, or supporting local music festivals. These initiatives not only enrich the cultural life of the community but also foster a sense of belonging and unity among its members.

Another significant advantage of musical patronage is its role in cultural preservation. Throughout history, patronage has been instrumental in preserving countless masterpieces and cultural heritage. Today, patrons continue this tradition by funding projects that preserve and promote historical and traditional music. This ensures that these musical traditions are not lost to time but are instead passed down to future generations.

However, musical patronage is not without its potential drawbacks. One of the main concerns is the dependency on patrons. Artists may become overly reliant on their patrons, which could compromise their artistic integrity. This could lead to a situation where artists are creating work to please their patrons rather than following their own creative vision. It is crucial that arts remain free from constraints other than those of the creators themselves.

Another potential issue is the concentration of wealth and power in the hands of a few patrons. This can perpetuate social hierarchies and favor artists with connections or privilege. It can also lead to a lack of meritocracy, where qualifications become secondary to loyalty. This could result in unqualified individuals occupying important positions in the music industry.

In my view, a healthy balance is the ideal solution. The market works well for popular styles of music, where artists can earn a living through sales and performances. However, I believe that there should always be some form of patronage to support music that may not be commercially viable but is culturally or artistically significant. For instance, state funding can support foundations dedicated to preserving national music heritage and education. Private and corporate patrons also play a crucial role in promoting new artists, especially those from lower-income backgrounds who may not have the connections or resources to showcase their work.

item.content:encoded:
The Shawm

The shawm is an ancient double-reed wind instrument, introduced to Europe during the Crusades, that is considered a predecessor to the modern oboe. Its sound is produced by blowing through a reed, causing it to vibrate. Shawms were played by medieval and Renaissance musicians and used in dance and ceremonial music.

The Viol

The viol is a bowed, string instrument that was popular during the 16th to 18th centuries. Its sound is produced by drawing a bow across its strings. It shares similarities in tuning and construction with the Renaissance lute. The viol is an ancestor of the modern violin family. It was played by chamber musicians and used in ensemble music.

The Crumhorn

The crumhorn is a Renaissance-era double reed woodwind that produces sound through a vibrating reed. Its cylindrical body curves upward at one end. The crumhorn is an early form of double reed instruments like the modern oboe or bassoon. It was played by court and street musicians during the Renaissance and used for dance music.

The Sackbut

The sackbut is an early form of slide trombone, played from the Renaissance through the Baroque eras. Its telescopic slide mechanism alters tube length to change pitches. Sound emanates from buzzing lips against a cupped mouthpiece. The sackbut was played by Renaissance and Baroque instrumental ensembles and used in a variety of secular and sacred musical contexts.

The Dulcian

The dulcian is a double reed ancestor of the bassoon that was popular 1550-1700. Like other double reeds, its sound comes from vibrating reeds. Dulcians were played by Renaissance and early Baroque instrumental consorts and used in chamber and orchestral settings.

The Clavichord

The clavichord is a stringed keyboard instrument that produces sound by striking its brass or iron strings with small metal blades called tangents. It was mainly used in the Late Middle Ages through the Classical era. The clavichord is a forerunner of the piano and other keyboard instruments. It was played primarily by amateur musicians to accompany songs or for personal enjoyment.

The Lute

The lute is a plucked string instrument and important precursor to the guitar. Its strings are plucked by the performer and its hollow body amplifies the sound. Lutes were extremely popular Renaissance instruments played by amateur and professional musicians. They were utilized in song accompaniment, chamber music, and solo performance.

I recently came across this piece on social media and quickly remembered of having heard it before in the TV show Mozart In The Jungle. However, I hadn’t given it much attention until now. I’ve just listened to the performance of the Orquesta Sinfónica Simón Bolívar conducted by Gustavo Dudamel.

This is the type of music I am naturaly drawn to. Great melodies combined with a dancing Latin rhythm is something that I find fits beautifully with an orchestral setting.

Here I found the instrumentation to be interesting, not only for the inclusion of non-traditional Western instruments like the Claves and the Guiro, but also the use of the violas as guitars with their strings being plucked.

The opening minutes of the piece have a medley-like quality, with various rhythms and tonal colors unfolding. From the smooth melodic start on the winds, passing to the strings and then a build-up of the piano before the full orchestra blows in a surge of powerful brass and percussion, instantly recognisable as a quintessential Latin sound.

This change in mood is perhaps what I liked more about this piece. The melodies are beautiful and soft, but when the rhythmic part enters in action, the whole piece gains an energy that is danceable and contagious.

Overall, I thoroughly enjoyed this piece, and since I’m not yet familiar with the work of Arturo Márquez, I’m eager to explore more of his compositions.

item.title: Assignment 4
item.dc:creator: Pedro
item.description: For this assignment, I listened to the recording of Prokofiev’s ‘Classical’ Symphony by the Frankfurt Radio Symphony conducted…
item.content:encoded:
For this assignment, I listened to the recording of Prokofiev’s ‘Classical’ Symphony by the Frankfurt Radio Symphony conducted by Alondra de la Parra (2020) and the recording of Pulcinella (1920) by Stravinsky played by the Orchestre Philharmonique de Radio France conducted by Barbara Hannigan (2021).

From a historical perspective, the premiere of “Pulcinella” in 1920 and the “Classical Symphony” in 1918 allows one to situate both works squarely in the aftermath of World War I. This was a period of cultural change that moved against the Romantic era, marked by emotional expressivity and complex harmonic language. After the apocalyptic experience of World War I, people started to favour practicality and realism in art and philosophy, instead of abstract and metaphysical concepts (Taruskin, 2010). In music, as Burkholder et al. (2014:798) state, this led to a move away from intense emotions, irrationality, yearning, individualism, and nationalism, towards a return to the values of an earlier, seemingly more civilised era, such as the Classical style.

When addressing the apparent paradox of twentieth-century composers employing eighteenth-century Classical idioms, it is helpful to leverage the concept of “Neoclassicism.” This term, as Burkholder et al. (2014:798) explains, denotes a deliberate evocation of the principles and forms associated with the music of pre-Romantic music, including Baroque. Neoclassicism in music emphasised simplicity, polished textures, and refined melodies, emphasising instrumental over vocal, standardising orchestras and forms like sonata and rondo. Both Stravinsky and Prokofiev can be found within this neoclassical framework, yet they applied these influences in uniquely individual ways.

The exploration of Igor Stravinsky’s “Pulcinella” unveils an interesting journey through musical experimentation mixed with homage to the musical past. Composed between 1919 and 1920, and premiered as a ballet in May 1920, “Pulcinella” emerged during a period when Stravinsky began to divert from his earlier Russian nationalist style, characterised by works like “The Rite of Spring,” to what would later be labelled as his neoclassical phase. In “Pulcinella,” Stravinsky recasts the music attributed to 18th-century composer Giovanni Battista Pergolesi and his contemporaries with a contemporary touch, embodying the initial states of neoclassicism in the early 20th century (Leitão, n.d.).

Although it is considered a hallmark in Stravinsky’s production, as a turning point in the composer’s style, there is no consensus about whether “Pulcinella” truly fits the neoclassical label. Unlike typical neoclassical compositions, where the borrowed material is often reworked to fit a more modern style, Stravinsky keeps much of the original material in “Pulcinella” unchanged. For Cross (2003:110), his additions seem more like an elegant enhancement or gloss on the existing material instead of a complete re-composition.

I respectfully diverge from Cross’ perspective. While I acknowledge that Stravinsky reproduces certain movements largely in their original form (such as the Overture, Serenata and Gavotta), I argue that he engages in substantial recomposition in other sections (e.g. Allegro assai and Vivo). It is imperative to go into specific examples to illustrate this further.

Listening to the overture, it is clear that there’s a classical sound to it. The memorable theme being played immediately at the beginning is a Gallant trait and a repetition with a slight change, resembling, for example, Mozart’s Eine Kleine Nachtmusik, K. 525. This theme undergoes variations throughout the piece, showcasing the classical hallmark of Ritornello, a musical device extensively utilised during the Baroque and classical periods.

The Sinfonia’s melody-dominated homophony and the contrapuntal exchange between bassoon and oboe work reinforce the Baroque feel (bars 7-9).

The classical feeling is further reinforced by the presence of traditional voice leading and the utilisation of perfect cadences. Ratner (1956) argues that in the Gallant style, full cadences are much more frequent and can be employed not only at the end but also within the composition. This is evident, for example, in the straightforward D major perfect cadence (bar 15).

Despite these classical hallmarks, subtle hints of modernity begin to emerge, such as the strategic use of dynamics to create a dramatic interpretation.

Stravinsky employs a similar compositional approach in the Serenade movement, adhering substantially to the original classical style of the piece while subtly integrating select modernist elements. The melody retains the lyrical, cantabile quality and thin homophonic accompaniment texture characteristic of the original composition. However, Stravinsky introduces hints of 20th-century harmonic practices such as the dissonant harmonisation supporting the sustained vocal note (bar 17-18).

This manipulation of the traditional harmonic language can often be subtle, cushioned within the familiar cadences of the classical style, as we’ve seen before. Yet at times, it can be unsettling, particularly when he introduces dissonant vertical sonorities, resembling The Rite of Spring, that challenge the listener’s expectations steeped in the conventions of tonal music. A notable instance is the Allegro assai, where a dissonant C minor 6th is repeated 21 times at the beginning and 33 times at the end, each time at Fortississimo. This kind of dissonant intensity diverges from the norms of the 18th century, where dissonances were promptly resolved.

The choice of instrumentation in the Vivo movement, specifically the pairing of contrabass and trombone, allows for striking timbral effects and contrasts that are far from a classical choice of instrumentation.

Furthermore, the choice of only wind instruments in the Gavotte is a deviation from the traditional classical orchestration, further explored by Stravinsky with the melodic line frequently alternating between the oboe and flute, with the lower register instruments also periodically assuming the melody. This is a clear deviation from typical Baroque era roles of clear melody versus accompaniment.

Looking at the suite as a whole, Stravinsky’s innovations emerge gradually. At first, the work resembles a straightforward orchestration of an 18th-century piece. As it continues, hints of Stravinsky’s style periodically appear, becoming increasingly obvious. The transformation culminates in the jazzy ending that foreshadows the sound Copland would later develop.

This oscillation between conformity and defiance of classical norms encapsulates the dual nature of “Pulcinella” that could be seen explored by Prokofiev two years before.

Prokofiev tried a different approach for what would later be understood as his first (if not the first ever) Neoclassical work. In his Symphony No. 1 in D major, Op. 25, commonly referred to as the “Classical” Symphony, instead of reworking pre-existing material from the classical era, he created a composition with original material but “in the style of Haydn” – Prokofiev, as cited in Robinson (1987: 130).

In this symphony, which premiered in 1918, Prokofiev consciously adopted classical forms for each movement of the symphony, such as the sonata form for the first movement, a slow lyrical second movement, a gavotte replacing the conventional minuet and trio for the third, and a lively Sonata for the finale. In each of these movements, Prokofiev maintained the hallmark of Classical music: brief, restrained, symmetrical, transparent and scored for a small Haydnesque ensemble (Robinson, 1987:185). The light and elegant texture created by the modest orchestration of two flutes, two oboes, two clarinets, two bassoons, two horns, two trumpets, timpani and strings employs a classical ambient to the overall sound.

On top of the classical four-movement structure as we’ve seen before, harmonically, the use of D major in the first, third, and fourth movements, with the second set in the dominant key, A major, reflects the Classical practice of tonal organisation.

The melodies are brought forward and are discernible. The thematic and melodic elements are employed economically, reminiscent of classical composition, transitioning across instrumentation to create timbral contrast. One clear example can be found in the second theme of the first movement, presented in bars 19-20, and explored in the subsequent measures.

Within the third movement’s Gavotte, a brief interplay of counterpoint arises. The middle segment maintains a homophonic texture dominated by a distinct melody; however, with the entrance of a counter melody in the solo oboe (bar 21), a two-part counterpoint emerges, reflecting an influence of the Baroque era.

In addition to form and melody, Prokofiev incorporates specific techniques linked to Haydn and Mozart. The sudden bursts in the opening bars of the first movement recall the famed Mannheim Rocket figures that Haydn adopted. The extra silent bar at the end of the exposition is a grand pause, another Mannheim trait meant to stress the sonata form’s architecture.

However, Prokofiev also differs from the Classical style. There are many unexpected key changes and distant modulations. For example, in the first movement he surprisingly, and almost provocatively, shifts from D major to C major.

Additionally, Prokofiev adds complex, syncopated rhythms beyond the Classical norm. Specifically in the development section in the first movement, the orchestra falls out of rhythmic alignment, introducing highly modern syncopations.

Finally, Prokofiev’s playful mixing of themes, witty contrasts and overall humour align more with the modernist inclination toward irony and satire than with the earnestness of the Classical symphonic tradition. His provocative modulations, such as initiating the recapitulation of the first movement in an unrelated C major, can be seen as a playful critique or jest at the conventions of classical music. This approach underscores his unique style, which often challenges and reinterprets traditional norms.

While both composers adopted a neoclassical approach in their respective pieces, it’s fascinating to listen to how each infused their compositions with distinct personal traits. Stravinsky, for instance, introduced his characteristic abrupt dynamics, unsettling repetitions and pushing the boundaries of instrumentation. On the other hand, Prokofiev employed his signature modulations and unexpected key changes. Here lies the beauty of neoclassicism. Its ability to evoke a sense of familiarity yet is full of novel elements waiting to be explored.

Word Count: 1578

Reflective Account


Engaging with this unit on the classical era of music history helped me develop several new skills. Most notably, I gained a much deeper understanding of the musical concept of neoclassicism. While I was familiar with the term in the context of visual arts, studying its application to music in assignment 4 gave me new insight. Realizing how cyclical arts tend to be was also an interesting takeaway. Artists often look back in time for inspiration, not usually to the immediate past but rather to more distant eras. I see this happening currently as more musicians use musical ideas, samples, and lexicon from the 80s and 90s, similar to how composers in the 1920s neoclassical period were inspired by the 18th-century classical period.

This assignment also allowed me to solidify my personal preferences within the genre. The dramatic shifts, unsettling sounds, and instrumental experimentation present in Stravinsky’s work deeply resonate with me. What truly impresses me is his ability to infuse classical forms with his unique style, influencing music for years to come. Stravinsky’s work embodies the spirit of innovation within a traditional framework, making him a composer I’m particularly drawn to.

However, this journey wasn’t without its challenges. My enthusiasm for research sometimes overshadowed the pure act of listening. Getting bogged down in historical details and technical aspects occasionally prevented me from simply experiencing the music on an emotional level. Moving forward, I plan to strike a balance between intellectual exploration and pure listening pleasure.

The exercise I found most valuable in developing my skills was explaining the essence of Haydn’s Symphony No. 104 in simple, clear terms. Distilling complex musical ideas and history concisely takes practice and I believe this strengthened my ability. On the other hand, comparing period orchestras to modern ones was disappointing, as I did not perceive the contrast I expected in their sounds. Perhaps I would select a different piece to better highlight their differences.

Listening to lesser-known composers beyond the trio of Mozart, Beethoven and Haydn brought welcome new perspectives. I was particularly intrigued by Muzio Clementi and hope to explore more of his and other contemporaneous composers’ work in the future. If I were to undertake a similar exercise again, I would set aside more time to go more deeply into the biographical details and compositional outputs of more minor classical-period figures, especially women. Their contributions to the development of the era’s predominant musical style deserve more attention than I could give them here.

Overall, I found this an exciting first step in more fully studying Western classical music. The discoveries I made have motivated me to continue learning more about music history across different eras. Understanding context opens up a greater appreciation of the compositions themselves, so I am eager to keep developing a richer framework through which to enjoy the fruits of musical geniuses past and present.

item.content:encoded:
Programme

The Marriage of Figaro is a comic opera composed by Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart, with an Italian libretto written by Lorenzo Da Ponte. It premiered in 1786 at the Burgtheater in Vienna. Based on the play La folle journée, ou le Mariage de Figaro by Pierre Beaumarchais, the opera tells the story of the clever servant Figaro, who is preparing to marry the vivacious Susanna. Their wedding day gets off to a rocky start, however, as their employer Count Almaviva tries to exercise his feudal right to bed the bride before the groom. The plot revolves around a single day filled with twists and turns, as various characters hatch plans to fool one another.

The opera is structured in four acts. Act I establishes the basic plot – Count Almaviva wants to seduce Figaro’s bride-to-be, Susanna and has abolished the medieval right of a lord to sleep with a servant girl on her wedding night to make his intentions seem more honourable. Figaro, the count’s servant, plots to outwit his master’s plans. In Act II, the Countess laments her husband’s infidelity while plotting with Susanna to publicly expose the Count’s plans to embarrass him. In Act III, complications arise with the adolescent page Cherubino, who has a crush on the Countess. There are disguises and much confusion before Susanna and the Countess expose the Count’s intentions. Finally, in Act IV all is resolved after much scheming, including multiple plans to dress up Cherubino as a girl. The Count begs for forgiveness, the Countess forgives him, and the opera ends with rejoicing over the two marriages – Figaro and Susanna, and the reunited Count and Countess Almaviva.

The Marriage of Figaro shows Mozart’s genius through brilliant ensemble writing and memorable melodies that capture the emotions of the drama. The overture introduces no less than 9 musical themes or theme fragments that set the mood for this opera. From the famed “Non più andrai” where Figaro teasingly says farewell to Cherubino’s carefree days, to the Countess’s hauntingly melancholy “Dove sono i bei momenti,” the opera overflows with musical riches. The finale of Act IV concludes the opera with one of Mozart’s most joyful and technically dazzling ensemble finales as all celebrate the happy outcome.

The Marriage of Figaro was an instant hit at its premiere and it has remained as one of the most popular operas for over 200 years. Its characters are recognizable archetypes depicting master-servant class tensions, marital infidelity and forgiveness, outwitting authority, and the confusion of young love. Musically and dramatically, the opera represents the height of the opera buffa (comic opera) genre with Mozart’s sublime music animating Da Ponte’s hilarious situations and characters. Performed frequently worldwide, The Marriage of Figaro continues to fascinate modern audiences.

Personal Review:

I just saw Mozart’s “The Marriage of Figaro” production by the RCM Opera Orchestra on YouTube. They delivered a delightful evening filled with humour, beautiful music, and impressive performances. While not a seasoned opera critic, I was captivated by the production, particularly the interplay between the skilled musicians and the engaging cast.

While largely traditional, the staging beautifully evoked the opulence of 18th-century Vienna. The classic sets and costumes felt timeless, allowing the focus to remain on the characters and their comedic antics. Sir Thomas Allen’s direction navigated the opera’s twists and turns, keeping the pace lively and the humour fresh.

The standout performances were truly captivating. Adam Maxey’s Figaro was a charming and endearing presence, his voice effortlessly conveying both wit and warmth. Julieth Lozano’s Susanna was a force of nature, her powerful and passionate vocals embodied the character’s intelligence and determination. The rest of the cast also impressed, with each singer delivering their roles with commitment and vocal skill.

However, the true highlight of the performance was the RCM Opera Orchestra. With the conductor Michael Rosewell, the musicians delivered a flawless performance. Their playing was tight, nuanced, and full of emotion, perfectly capturing the wide range of moods in Mozart’s score. From the brilliant Overture to the dramatic climaxes, the orchestra provided a solid foundation for the singers and truly elevated the overall experience.

While the individual performances were strong, the most memorable aspect of the production was the seamless collaboration between the orchestra and the cast. The final scene, where the music and characters come together in a joyful celebration of love and forgiveness, was truly magical.

While I might not be an expert, I felt that the RCM Opera Orchestra’s “The Marriage of Figaro” was thoroughly entertaining.

item.content:encoded:
In the early 18th century, music publishing centered around major cities like London, Amsterdam, and Paris. Publishers like John Walsh in London helped popularize Italian instrumental music and songs from London’s theater scene. Engraving allowed more music to be published and distributed across Europe. Meanwhile, the Ballard family held a monopoly on music printing in France, restricting publishing there.

Around 1750, Johann Gottlob Immanuel Breitkopf in Leipzig started experimenting with different printing methods to make sheet music more widely available. He used a combination of movable type, engraving, and manuscript copies . His editions were cheaper than engraved music, allowing him to distribute music more widely and create new markets. Breitkopf helped popularize the German sentimental song genre. Other German publishers like Hartknoch, Rellstab, and Schwickert adopted his techniques.

The onset of the 18th century witnessed a significant shift in music publishing, particularly with the commercial use of engraving. This method allowed for faster production and distribution of music, a stark contrast to the heavy movable type and manuscript copying that had been predominately used. Although manuscript copies and letterpress printing of music continued throughout the century, the development of engraving led to a more extensive and competitive music publication market.

London’s music publishing scene thrived around 1700, closely followed by Paris between 1740 and 1760, Vienna just before 1780, and Leipzig around 1800. Each city, in its prime, contributed to the cumulative growth of available published music, fostering a competitive environment that spurred public interest in music. This period intertwined with the rising of the middle class, whose demand for printed music became insatiable. Amateur music-making at home became a widespread phenomenon, breaking the monopoly of professional concerts and bringing music into the intimate circles of family and friends. This change democratized music, making it accessible to a wider audience beyond the aristocracy and religious institutions that had previously dominated musical patronage.

The engraving method, which began in London and Amsterdam, facilitated the international distribution of copies through Northern and Western Europe, propelling the music of Italian masters and others to unprecedented popularity. The success and efficiency of engraving caught on quickly, with publishers in major cities adopting the technique and contributing to its refinement. This led to an increased production of instrumental music and operatic scores, bringing a wider variety of music to the public.

In London, the music publishing industry saw significant growth under figures like John Walsh, who became the principal publisher of Handel’s music. Through such publishers, a more organized and expansive distribution system emerged, bringing music to more people than ever before. In parallel, similar developments occurred in Paris and Vienna, each adapting the engraving method to their unique cultural contexts and musical tastes, thus enriching the diversity of music available in the public domain.

The influence of music publishing in this era extended far beyond the mere accessibility of music. It catalyzed a shift in musical tastes, with public concerts becoming more popular and the amateur musician trend fostering a new consumer base for publishers. This period marked a crucial point in the history of music, where the production and consumption of music witnessed revolutionary changes, setting the stage for the dynamic developments in music publishing that would continue into the 19th century and beyond.

References

Boorman, S., Selfridge-Field, E. and Krummel, D.W. (2014) ‘Printing and publishing of music’, in Grove Music Online, Oxford Music Online [Online], Oxford, Oxford University Press. Available at http://www.oxfordmusiconline.com.libezproxy.open.ac.uk/subscriber/article/grove/music/40101pg2.

item.title: Listening to Beethoven – Symphony No. 1 in C major, Op. 21
item.dc:creator: Pedro
item.description: As the lovely and gradual introduction in the first movement gets underway, the anticipation for a strong cadence…
item.content:encoded:
As the lovely and gradual introduction in the first movement gets underway, the anticipation for a strong cadence builds and builds, but it doesn’t arrive. The music is constantly leaving you on a hook and, just when you think it can’t get any more energetic, the strings drop into tune and the winds have a moment of stillness. At last, the cadence arrives but the pace never lets up throughout the movement, toying with your expectations throughout. It’s a back-and-forth of suspense and surprise, the whole way up to a glorious conclusion that couldn’t leave you in any doubt of the music’s full force.

The second movement has the feel of classical formality, with a subject and then periods of rest. At first, the emotional restraint in this movement might make it less engaging, but the dramatic volume level gives the music layers of interest that will keep you listening.

Beethoven scores more points with dynamic change and strong contrast in the third movement. These are hallmarks of his style, and you can see why people, like me for example, just really enjoy listening to his music.

The symphony’s final movement starts dramatically and commands attention immediately. Throughout this movement, it feels like Beethoven is deliberately playing with the listener’s expectations again, creating moments where the orchestra resembles a choir and leading the listener to anticipate a conclusion, only to defy those expectations. The movement maintains a sense of suspense and anticipation, keeping the listener engaged until the very end.
